awd_titl_txt: RR: Building a Robust Foundation for Measuring Material Wealth in Low- and Middle-Income Settings
awd_abstract_narration:
A household's economic status is one of the strongest and most consistent predictors of a range of policy-relevant outcomes - including child growth, adult nutritional status, fertility, and cognitive function and development.  In high-income settings, household income is frequently used to measure economic status. However, in low-income settings, researchers usually must rely on alternative measures based on what a household owns and what basic services it has access to.  Every year, hundreds of studies by social scientists and policymakers use these asset-based measures of wealth to examine how household economic status shapes human development and to evaluate poverty alleviation efforts and economic growth.  However, current asset-based measures rely on untested assumptions about how households can reach economic prosperity and whether there are multiple pathways to economic advancement in different contexts.  The current project will determine the validity and robustness of different asset-based methods for estimating household wealth using samples representing over 80% of the world's current population.  This will provide a robust foundation for the measurement of household wealth in applied social science and public policy fields, including economic development and population health, which frequently rely on asset-based measures for identifying disparities and at-risk populations.

The proposed project takes a two-pronged approach to assess which measures of household wealth best capture policy-relevant benchmarks of achievement.  Such benchmarks will include physical growth, educational attainment, and personal and community assessments of satisfaction and relative economic standing. At a macro-level, the project expands on an ongoing 6-year project compiling and analyzing household wealth measures in over 120 low- and middle-income countries.  At a micro-level, the project focuses on several communities that vary in terms of livelihood - farming, fishing, livestock, and rural/urban wage labor - and cultural background.  The findings and data tools from the project will build a foundation for future researchers to assess economic resources that are both locally meaningful and broadly comparable and that can improve our understanding of the linkages of material wealth with human outcomes across a range of communities.

por.por_cntn:
A household’s economic status is one of the strongest and most consistent predictors of a range of policy-relevant outcomes—including child growth, adult nutritional status, fertility, and cognitive function and development.  In high-income settings, researchers frequently use household income to assess economic status. However, in low-income settings, researchers usually must rely on alternative measures based on what a household owns and what basic services it has access to.  Every year, hundreds of studies by social scientists and policymakers use a variety of asset-based measures of wealth to examine how household economic status shapes human development and to evaluate poverty alleviation efforts and economic growth. 

The project investigated the relative performance of different asset-based wealth measures as well as the validity of the assumptions underlying different measures.   It combined in-depth study of 10 communities in rural Bangladesh with a broad analysis of worldwide samples representing over 80% of the world’s current population. 

The project team found that in over 40 countries worldwide, there are two distinct dimensions of wealth—one associated with success in cash economies and one associated with success in agricultural activities .  We further showed that these agricultural wealth measures complement existing asset-based wealth indices that are biased towards wealth derived from cash economies. Using these multiple dimensions of wealth, we have shown that how wealth is defined and measured can fundamentally modify associations of wealth with a range of outcomes, including: (1) mental health, (2) fertility , and (3) HIV risk in sub-Saharan Africa. 

Focusing on the cash economy dimension in a sample of 84 countries worldwide, we further found that a wealth estimate with universal weighting for a limited set of common assets performed best in predicting a range of outcomes, including childhood growth and self, community, and objective assessments of economic standing.  Moreover, we showed that indices that rely on GDP per capita to harmonize across countries perform much worse than purely asset-based measures.

The project has led to the following training outcomes:  Three graduate students have received training in analysis of interview and sociodemographic data, and database management and analysis in R and SPSS.  Over the course of the grant, a total of 74 undergraduates and six graduate students have been trained in the lab, with over 40% under-represented minorities.  Eleven of these undergraduates have received training in research methods and theories to complete independent student-driven projects.

Our team has published papers using these new wealth measures in journals from diverse fields, including anthropology, demography, economics, and development studies. The project-developed tools for estimating multiple dimensions of wealth are also being incorporated by our partner organization in Bangladesh to improve identification of vulnerable populations in their area.
